biography:
David Chesworth's distinctive compositions and installations have been performed and exhibited extensively in Australia as well as the Americas, Europe and Japan. Major festivals which have featured his work include Ars Electronica, Festival D?Automne de Paris, Edinburgh Festival, Melbourne International Festival, and SoundCulture.

David Chesworth is director of the David Chesworth Ensemble - regarded as one of Australia's premier musical ensembles. The eight-piece ensemble is dedicated to performing Chesworth?s music. Over eight years the ensemble has evolved a musical approach and performance style that is truly unique. The ensemble?s first CD, 'Exotica Suite', was nominated for an Aria award in 1995 and their second CD, 'Badlands', will shortly be released in the United States. The ensemble has given numerous performances including the Melbourne Festival with Gavin Bryars. In 2001 The ensemble has been invited to perform a series of concerts in New York, including the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Downunder Festival and the Bang on a Can Marathon.

Together with collaborator Sonia Leber, David Chesworth is a director of Wax Sound Media, which has created a series of innovative public-art and museum installations including the recently completed 5,000 Calls, a permanent 'sonic environment' for the surrounds of the Sydney Olympic Stadium for the 2000 Olympics and beyond. Other projects include The Persuaders, a multi-media work commissioned by Cinemedia for the Gallery of the Moving Image at Melbourne?s Federation Square.

Chesworth's work has always involved an investigation into relationships between the performers, audience and the ?work? itself. His interest in combining sound and musical elements and exploring wider extra-musical contexts has led to his involvement with performance and opera. His first opera, Insatiable, was completed in 1986. Since then, he has worked regularly with Melbourne?s Chamber Made Opera (works include Recital, The Two Executioners and Lacuna), and with the Melbourne Festival (Domepiece and Sabat Jesus). A new CD, 'Wicked Voice', containing material from these productions is available on ABC Classics. Chesworth has recently completed Cosmonaut, a major new work for Opera Australia.

Southgate, scored for the 1991 Southgate opening in Melbourne, received an international Prix Ars Electronica award. Sabat-Jesus was selected to represent Australia in the 1994 Paris International Rostrum of Composers. Insatiable received the 1988 A.T.O.M. Award for Most Innovative Film, and The Two Executioners received the inaugural Age Performing Arts Award for the Most Outstanding Fringe Performance. In 1997 he was awarded a Churchill Fellowship to pursue studies with opera composers including Robert Ashley and Gavin Bryars. In 2001 he received a Green Room Award for Sound Design in Drama.
